1.learning_goal: Web Pages, End to End: In this unit, students will learn how the web loads pages from browser to server and back, then build a small multi-page site using HTML structure, semantic layout, links, images, lists, and basic forms with correct paths and attributes.

chapters.title: How the Web Talks
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how browsers, clients, and servers work together through requests and responses to load web pages, files, and resources. Understand URLs and paths well enough to trace what happens from typing a URL to seeing a page—or an error—in the browser.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Browser and Client
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define browser and client in a web page scenario; Describe what the browser does with HTML/CSS/JS at a high level; Identify what the user controls vs what the browser controls

lessons.title: Server and Response
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define server and response; List common response files (HTML, CSS, JS, images); Understand what it means to “serve a file”

lessons.title: Request in Plain Words
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define request using everyday examples (page load, image load); Trace “type URL → request → response → render”; Predict what happens when a request fails (missing page/file)

lessons.title: URLs and Paths
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify URL parts: domain + path + query (conceptually); Distinguish URL path vs local file path; Understand why correct paths matter for loading resources

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Browser and client basics
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to clearly distinguish what the user (client) controls vs what the browser does automatically when loading a web page. Output: A completed written/typed worksheet where you label roles (user vs browser) in different browsing scenarios.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Server and response scenarios
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to explain what a server is and match different types of response files (HTML, CSS, JS, images) to real-world examples of what appears in the browser. Output: A set of matched pairs and short written explanations that connect file types to what the browser shows.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Following a request step-by-step
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to trace the full journey “type URL → request → response → render” and predict what happens when a request fails. Output: A hand-drawn or digital flow diagram with annotations describing each step and what happens on success vs failure.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: URLs and paths detective
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to identify the domain, path, and query parts of a URL and distinguish them from local file paths. Output: A marked-up list of example URLs and file paths where each part is labeled and mis-labeled examples are corrected.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Web story case study
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to read a short story about visiting a website and correctly identify all mentions of browser, client, server, request, response, and URL parts. Output: An annotated story where key phrases are highlighted and categorized into the correct web concepts.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Building Your First HTML Pages
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how HTML structures a page using elements, tags, and attributes, and practice creating simple multi-page sites with clear headings, text, and links between pages.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: HTML Elements
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define HTML as page structure; Create a page using common elements (h1, p, a); Use headings to create a readable structure

lessons.title: HTML Elements vs Tags
lessons.learning_outcomes: Understand difference between elements and tags; Identify and understand the opening and closing tag; Identify and understand self-closing tags

lessons.title: HTML Attributes
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify an attribute as name="value" on a tag; Use common attributes correctly (href, src, alt); Understand what “value” means in an attribute context

lessons.title: Links Between Pages
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create links between index.html and about.html; Use relative paths correctly; Debug a broken link by fixing the path; Understand the difference between internal and external links

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Personal intro page
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to create a simple HTML page using h1 and p elements to form a clear structure. Output: A basic personal introduction web page with a main heading and several well-structured paragraphs.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Story article structure
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to use multiple heading levels (h1, h2, h3) and paragraphs to organize a short article into readable sections. Output: An HTML “article” page where sections like introduction, main story, and conclusion are clearly separated by headings.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Element and tag spotter
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to correctly identify HTML elements, their opening and closing tags, and self-closing tags within a small code sample. Output: An annotated HTML snippet where each tag is labeled as opening, closing, or self-closing and paired with its element.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Attributes in a mini profile
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to use common HTML attributes (href, src placeholder-only in text, alt as concept) and explain what the attribute values mean. Output: A small HTML profile snippet containing links with href attributes and at least one tag with another attribute and explained values in comments.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Two-page mini site
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to create index.html and about.html and correctly link them together using relative paths and internal vs external links. Output: A two-page mini website where clicking navigation links moves you between index and about pages and to one external site.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Building Simple Semantic Websites
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to structure multi-page websites with semantic HTML, meaningful headings, accessible images, and consistent navigation, then practice by building and refining a small cafe site.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Images and Alt Text
lessons.learning_outcomes: Load images from an assets folder using correct paths; Add meaningful alt text (basic accessibility); Fix broken images by reasoning about file location

lessons.title: Semantic Page Layout
lessons.learning_outcomes: Build a page with header, nav, main, section, footer; Understand what semantic HTML means (simple definition); Organize content into clear sections (not random divs)

lessons.title: Three Pages, One Site
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create index.html, about.html, contact.html; Keep navigation consistent across pages; Understand how the browser loads different pages via links

lessons.title: Headings That Make Sense
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use one h1 per page and structure sections with h2; Fix a page with messy heading levels; Understand why hierarchy matters for readability

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Image gallery card
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to load images from an assets folder using correct relative paths and add meaningful alt text. Output: A simple HTML page showing at least three images with descriptive alt text and no broken image icons.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe homepage layout
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to build a semantic page layout using header, nav, main, section, and footer to organize content. Output: A “Cafe” homepage with a clear header, navigation menu, main content sections, and a footer, all using semantic elements.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Three-page cafe site - Part 1
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to create index.html, about.html, and contact.html files and give each page a meaningful h1 and basic content. Output: Three separate HTML files representing the home, about, and contact pages of a simple cafe website.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Three-page cafe site - Part 2
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to keep navigation consistent across pages and ensure links correctly load each page in the browser. Output: A three-page site where each page has the same navigation bar and all internal links work correctly.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Fixing messy headings
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to reorganize a page’s headings to use one h1 and a logical hierarchy of h2 (and optional h3) for readability. Output: A corrected HTML document where previously jumbled headings are now in a clear, accessible outline.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Structuring Pages with Lists and Forms
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to structure real page content using lists and div-based sections, and to build basic forms with clear inputs and helpful placeholders. By the end, you’ll create simple menus, navigation, layouts, and login/contact forms that are readable, usable, and easy to extend.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Lists for Real Content
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use ul/ol/li for actual content (menu items, steps, features); Choose the right list type for the purpose; Combine lists with links for simple navigation patterns

lessons.title: Clean Sections with Divs
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use div to group content when semantics don’t fit; Add classes to divs to label page sections; Keep a layout readable using consistent grouping

lessons.title: Form Inputs and Values
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define input and value in plain terms (the HTML element vs what the user types); Use common input types (text, email, password) and understand what changes; Add and explain the placeholder attribute (hint text, not the actual value)

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Restaurant menu list
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to use ul, ol, and li elements to represent real content like menu items and choose the appropriate list type. Output: A restaurant menu page where appetizers, mains, and desserts are displayed as well-structured lists.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Task steps checklist
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to represent ordered steps (like a recipe or setup guide) using an ordered list and explain why order matters. Output: An HTML page showing a clear, numbered checklist or step-by-step guide.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Simple navigation list
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to combine lists with links to create a basic navigation menu using an unordered list of anchor elements. Output: A small HTML snippet where a horizontal or vertical nav menu is built from a ul containing linked li items.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Page layout with div groups
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to group related content using div elements and add class names to label different page sections. Output: An HTML layout where content is grouped into clearly class-labeled divs such as .hero, .features, and .footer-area.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Login form basics
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to create a simple login form using text, email, and password input types and explain the difference between input and its value. Output: An HTML login form with labeled fields that accept user input and visually show typed values (with password masked).

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Contact form with placeholders
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to add placeholder attributes to form inputs to provide hint text without setting actual values. Output: A contact form page where each input field displays helpful placeholder text that disappears when the user starts typing.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Weekly Review
chapters.learning_goals: Review key concepts learned during the week and complete the weekly assessment.

lessons.title: Weekly Review Prep Session
lessons.learning_outcomes: We'll review key concepts and prepare for the assessment

lessons.title: Prep Lesson
lessons.learning_outcomes: Prep lesson for the weekly review

lessons.title: Weekly Review Assessment
lessons.learning_outcomes: Our weekly assessment, where you will test your knowledge from the last week using practical questions and challenges

2.learning_goal: HTML, CSS, and Interaction: In this unit, students will structure accessible HTML pages, apply reusable CSS for layout and typography, debug with DevTools, and use JavaScript with DOM events to add basic interactive behavior.

chapters.title: Clean HTML, Accessible Pages
chapters.learning_goals: Build well-structured, readable HTML and apply basic accessibility habits while you start styling with CSS. You’ll practice semantic landmarks, alt text, and core selectors, and use DevTools to inspect and fix real page structures.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: HTML Quality Habits
lessons.learning_outcomes: Keep HTML consistently indented and readable; Spot and fix broken nesting and missing closing tags; Use DevTools Elements tab to confirm structure

lessons.title: Basic Accessibility Habits
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use semantic landmarks (nav, main) intentionally; Add alt text and proper labels reliably; Identify 2-3 easy accessibility improvements on a page

lessons.title: CSS: Three Ways
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply CSS inline (style="") for quick tests; Apply CSS in a <style> tag for page-level styling; Link an external CSS file with <link> for reuse

lessons.title: Selectors: Tag, Class, ID
lessons.learning_outcomes: Write selectors using tag, class, and id; Predict which elements a selector targets; Fix a selector that styles the wrong elements

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe menu markup
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice clean indentation, proper nesting/closing of tags, and semantic landmarks while building a simple cafe menu page. Output: A single HTML page showing a cafe menu with correctly structured and readable HTML.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Travel blog accessibility check
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply basic accessibility habits by adding alt text, labels, and landmarks to a small travel blog page. Output: An HTML page where images, navigation, and main content are accessible with clear alt text and ARIA/labels.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Style methods playground
lessons.learning_outcomes: Compare inline styles, a <style> tag, and an external CSS file by styling the same simple profile card three different ways. Output: An HTML + CSS setup where the same content is styled via inline, internal, and external CSS.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Selector clinic
lessons.learning_outcomes: Reinforce tag, class, and id selectors by fixing and writing selectors to style specific parts of a “mini news site” layout. Output: A styled HTML page where headlines, bylines, and sections are correctly targeted by CSS selectors.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: DevTools structure inspection
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use the DevTools Elements tab to inspect, debug, and correct a deliberately broken HTML page (nesting, closing tags, wrong elements). Output: A fixed HTML file whose structure matches the intended layout as verified via DevTools.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Text and Layout Basics
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to style text and visual sections with CSS, control spacing using the box model, and understand block vs inline behavior. By the end, you’ll combine these skills to build clean, readable pages with consistent typography and simple layouts.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Styling Text Tags
lessons.learning_outcomes: Style headings and paragraphs (size, spacing, alignment); Improve readability with consistent text styling; Keep styles consistent across multiple pages

lessons.title: Divs and Visual Blocks
lessons.learning_outcomes: Style div sections using background, padding, borders; Create clear sections of a page using CSS; Use classes to apply the same styling pattern repeatedly

lessons.title: Box Model Spacing
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply margin vs padding intentionally; Understand spacing using box model vocabulary; Use DevTools to inspect margin and padding live

lessons.title: Block vs Inline
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish block vs inline behavior; Use display: inline-block for simple layout needs; Debug “why won’t these sit next to each other?” issues

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Blog typography
lessons.learning_outcomes: Style headings and paragraphs in a mini blog page for consistent size, spacing, and alignment across multiple pages. Output: Two simple blog HTML pages that share consistent, readable text styling via a common CSS file.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Portfolio sections
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use divs, background colors, padding, borders, and reusable classes to create clear visual sections on a personal portfolio page. Output: A one-page portfolio with visually distinct header, projects, and contact sections styled via classes.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Product card spacing
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply margin and padding intentionally on “product cards” while inspecting the box model in DevTools. Output: A grid of product cards with well-balanced internal padding and external margins, verified via DevTools.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Navigation layout
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish block vs inline elements and use display: inline-block to create a simple horizontal navigation bar. Output: A basic navigation menu whose links sit neatly in a row with controlled spacing and hover styling.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Text and blocks review
lessons.learning_outcomes: Combine text styling, div sections, box model spacing, and display behavior to refine a small “event announcement” landing page. Output: A compact event page with well-spaced sections and readable typography using all learned CSS basics.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Layout, Forms, and First Scripts
chapters.learning_goals: Build simple floated layouts, style reusable buttons and form inputs, and debug CSS using DevTools. Connect a JavaScript file, verify it runs with console.log, and combine these skills into small, polished practice pages.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Simple Layout with Float
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create a basic two-column or image+text layout using float; Clear floats to prevent layout issues; Understand how float changes normal flow

lessons.title: Buttons and Inputs
lessons.learning_outcomes: Style buttons with hover and focus states (basic usability); Style inputs for consistent form design; Keep button and input styles reusable via classes

lessons.title: CSS Debugging in DevTools
lessons.learning_outcomes: Find where a style is coming from in the Styles panel; Identify why a style isn’t applying (wrong selector or wrong file); Make a test change in DevTools, then apply it in code

lessons.title: JavaScript Adds Behavior
lessons.learning_outcomes: Understand what JavaScript is used for on a web page; Link a script.js file correctly; Use console.log to confirm the script runs

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Two-column article layout
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use float to create a two-column article layout with an image floated beside text and clear floats to avoid layout issues. Output: An article page where an image and text sit side-by-side and the footer displays correctly below.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Signup form styling
lessons.learning_outcomes: Style inputs and buttons in a signup form with hover and focus states, keeping styles reusable via classes. Output: A styled signup form with consistent input fields and buttons that visually respond to hover and focus.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: DevTools CSS detective
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use DevTools to trace where a style comes from, debug why certain styles don’t apply, and then fix them in the code. Output: A corrected CSS + HTML pair where previously “broken” styles now apply as intended.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: JavaScript console ping
lessons.learning_outcomes: Link a script file to an HTML page and use console.log to confirm the script runs and basic behavior hooks are in place. Output: A web page that logs clear messages to the browser console when loaded and when a button is clicked.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Float and form mini page
lessons.learning_outcomes: Combine float layout, styled buttons/inputs, and DevTools debugging to polish a “newsletter + image” mini page. Output: A small layout with a floated image and a styled newsletter form, visually debugged and refined via DevTools.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: DOM Events in Action
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how to find elements in the DOM, attach and debug click/submit events, and update on‑page text dynamically by building small, focused projects like counters, forms, quotes, and to‑do lists.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: DOM: Find Elements
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define DOM in practical terms (page structure JS can access); Select elements with querySelector; Store elements in variables for reuse

lessons.title: Events: Click and Submit
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define an event (click, submit, input); Attach event listeners and run a function; Debug “event not firing” using console logs

lessons.title: Change Text on Click
lessons.learning_outcomes: Update text content of an element on click; Understand what changed in the DOM (content changed); Keep logic small and readable (one clear function)

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: DOM element finder
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use querySelector to select key elements on a “profile card” page and store them in variables for reuse. Output: A script that selects and logs specific DOM elements (name, avatar, bio) to the console.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Click counter
lessons.learning_outcomes: Attach a click event listener to a button and update a visible count, debugging any event issues with console logs. Output: A page where clicking a button increments and displays a counter on screen.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Simple feedback form submit
lessons.learning_outcomes: Attach a submit event listener to a form, prevent default behavior, and log the entered values for basic debugging. Output: A feedback form that, on submit, shows the captured input values in the console instead of reloading.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Quote changer
lessons.learning_outcomes: Update the text content of a quote element when a button is clicked, keeping the logic in a small, clear function. Output: A page where clicking a button replaces the current quote text with a different quote.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: To-do list text updates - Part 1
lessons.learning_outcomes: Find DOM elements and wire up basic click events to add static list items to a to-do list area. Output: A page where clicking an “Add sample task” button inserts predefined tasks into a visible list.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: To-do list text updates - Part 2
lessons.learning_outcomes: Extend the to-do list by reading input values, responding to submit/click events, and updating list text dynamically. Output: A page where users can type a task, submit it, and see it appear in the to-do list instantly.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Weekly Review
chapters.learning_goals: Review key concepts learned during the week and complete the weekly assessment.

lessons.title: Weekly Review Prep Session
lessons.learning_outcomes: We'll review key concepts and prepare for the assessment

lessons.title: Prep Lesson
lessons.learning_outcomes: Prep lesson for the weekly review

lessons.title: Weekly Review Assessment
lessons.learning_outcomes: Our weekly assessment, where you will test your knowledge from the last week using practical questions and challenges
